questions.text: A patient came with the complaints of fatigue and difficulty breathing. On examination, distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds were found. X-ray is shown below. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.explanation:
Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

Fatigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

A chronic alcoholic patient with alcoholic liver disease was given some anti-amoebic drugs. Later, the patient presented with nausea, vomiting, flushing and hypotension. What is the likely diagnosis
A patient has a fever, rash, and eschar formation due to a mite bite. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in scrub vegetation i.e. low-lying trees and bushes.
  • The bite of infected trombiculid mites transmits it.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

  • The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

All of the below are features of Conn's syndrome except?
questions.explanation:
Conn Syndrome / Primary Hyperaldosteronism

Definition

Primary hyperaldosteronism characterized by excessive aldosterone secretion from adrenal glands with suppressed plasma renin

Epidemiology
  • Most common cause of secondary hypertension (6-20% of adult hypertensive patients)
  • Higher prevalence in resistant hypertension (up to 30%)
  • 2x more common in women

Etiology
  • Aldosterone-producing adenoma (50-60%)
  • Bilateral idiopathic adrenal hyperplasia
  • Aldosterone-producing adrenal carcinoma (1%)
  • Familial hyperaldosteronism (Types 1-3)

Pathophysiology
  • ↑ Aldosterone → ↑ Na+ reabsorption → plasma volume expansion
  • ↑ K+ excretion → hypokalemia
  • Can lead to tissue inflammation and fibrosis in heart, kidneys, vasculature

Clinical Features
  • Resistant hypertension
  • Muscle weakness/cramping
  • Fatigue
  • Headaches
  • Polydipsia/polyuria
  • NO edema (due to spontaneous natriuresis)

Lab Findings
  • ↓ K+ (can be normal in up to 38%)
  • ↑ Na+
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • ↑ Urinary K+ excretion (>30 mmol/day)
  • Suppressed plasma renin
  • ↑ Aldosterone-to-renin ratio (ARR)

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Initial screening: ARR >40
  • Confirmatory tests:
    • Salt loading test
    • Fludrocortisone suppression test
    • Captopril suppression test
  • Imaging: CT scan for adenoma
  • Adrenal venous sampling for lateralization

Treatment
  • Adenoma: Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Bilateral hyperplasia: Medical management
  • Medical options:
    • Spironolactone (first-line)
    • Eplerenone
    • Amiloride

Prognosis
  • Surgery: 30-60% cure rate for adenomas
  • High morbidity/mortality if untreated
  • May need long-term BP monitoring

High-Yield Associations
  • Normal K+ doesn't exclude diagnosis
  • No edema despite hyperaldosteronism
  • Screen all resistant hypertension cases

questions.text: What type of sanitation facilities should be provided for the soldiers returning from war?
The investigation of choice for ovarian torsion is?
questions.explanation:
Ovarian Torsion - Clinical Overview

Definition

Twisting of ovary and fallopian tube around supportive ligaments

Incidence
  • 3% of gynecologic emergencies
  • 20-25% cases occur during pregnancy

Risk Factors
  • Ovarian masses (6-10 cm)
  • Pregnancy
  • Long utero-ovarian ligaments
  • Right side more common (due to sigmoid colon on left)
  • Pathologically enlarged ovaries

Clinical Presentation
  • Sharp lower abdominal pain (sudden onset)
  • Intermittent worsening
  • Localized to involved side
  • Radiation to flank, groin, or thigh
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Low-grade fever

Diagnostic Methods
  • USG Doppler (investigation of choice)
  • Shows swollen edematous ovary
  • Disruption in normal adnexal flow
  • Free fluid in peritoneal cavity

Management
  • Rapid surgical intervention
  • Detorsion recommended initially
  • Cystectomy if mass present
  • Oophorectomy if necrosis present
  • Consider ovarian conservation regardless of appearance

Pregnancy Considerations
  • Management similar to non-pregnant state
  • Progesterone support if corpus luteum removed
  • Wait 10 weeks before additional surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is the next appropriate step in management after the failure of the McRobert maneuver in a case of shoulder dystocia?

A 27-year-old woman discovers a well-defined mobile and rubbery breast lump measuring 4x7 cm on self-examination. The lesion is painless and has been stable over several months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Fibroadenoma

Definition
  • Benign tumours arising from the proliferation of glandular tissue in the breast

Prevalence
  • Most common in women aged 15-25 years.

Aetiology
  • Believed to be influenced by hormonal fluctuations during reproductive years
  • Molecular alteration: Alterations in MED12 gene.

Clinical Presentation
  • Painless, firm, rubbery, and mobile lumps
  • Described as feeling like a "marble in the breast."

Histopathology

  • Well-defined borders due to a fibrous capsule, with proliferating stroma potentially compressing and distorting glandular components.
  • The epithelium may be of 2 patterns:
    • Pericanalicular Pattern: Surrounded by stroma
    • Intracanalicular Pattern: Compressed and distorted by it.

Mammogram

Popcorn calcification on mammogram

Diagnosis
  • Triple Assessment: Clinical examination, radiological imaging (ultrasound), tissue sampling (core-needle biopsy)
  • Ultrasound: Helps distinguish fibroadenomas from cysts
  • Core-Needle Biopsy: Provides definitive diagnosis

Treatment
  • Conservative Management: Watchful waiting, regular monitoring
  • Surgical Excision: For larger fibroadenomas, those causing symptoms, or uncertain diagnosis
  • Giant Fibroadenomas: Over 5 cm, may require excision through submammary incision

Prognosis
  • Benign, does not increase the risk of breast cancer
  • Growth can vary, influenced by hormonal changes
  • Recurrence is uncommon

Relationship to ANDI
  • Categorised according to ANDI as:
    • Normal: Small fibroadenomas (≤1 cm)
    • Disorder: Larger fibroadenomas (≤3 cm)
    • Disease: Giant fibroadenomas (>3 cm), multiple fibroadenomas

questions.explanation:
Specimen

Importance

Blood

Primary specimen; collect from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins to avoid contamination.

Preservative: Lithium heparin or EDTA tube, fluoride/oxalate, if alcohol is suspected

 

Urine

Useful for detecting parent compounds and metabolites of poisons.

Preservative: No preservative, sodium fluoride is added, if alcohol is

Suspected (Option A)

 

Gastric Contents

Helps identify ingested poisons and their concentrations through vomitus and stomach contents analysis.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison.(Option D)

Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid (Option C)

.

Liver

Analyzes metabolism and concentration of drugs; critical when blood/urine concentrations are low. Bile can detect specific substances like chlorpromazine and morphine.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison. Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid.

Hair and Nails

Detects heavy metal poisoning; metals accumulate in keratin. Neutron activation analysis identifies specific metals and exposure patterns.

Scene Residues

Provides clues about the poison through materials found at the scene, such as tablets or empty containers.

questions.text: Which malarial drug for plasmodium vivax drug is used to prevent relapse in the post-partum period?
questions.explanation:
Malaria in Pregnancy

Epidemiology
  • Most common in sub-Saharan Africa and India
  • Affects children under 5 years and pregnant women most severely
  • Congenital malaria develops in <5% of neonates born to infected mothers

Clinical Features
  • Fever, chills, flu-like symptoms
  • Less severe with recurrences
  • P. falciparum may cause kidney failure, coma, death
  • Pregnant women often asymptomatic due to partial immunity

Complications
  • Maternal: Anemia, kidney failure
  • Fetal: Stillbirth, premature birth, low birthweight
  • Placental: High levels of parasitemia
  • Approximately 16% of low birthweight births in Africa attributed to maternal malaria

Diagnosis
  • Microscopic evaluation of blood smear (gold standard)
  • Lower sensitivity in pregnancy due to low parasite densities
  • Malaria-specific antigens used for rapid testing
  • All infected patients from endemic areas should be tested with antimalarial drug resistance

Treatment
  • Chloroquine-sensitive P. vivax/P. ovale: Chloroquine
  • P. falciparum: Hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine
  • Multidrug-resistant P. falciparum: Artemisinin-based therapy

Prevention
  • Chemoprophylaxis recommended for endemic areas
  • Vector control: Insecticide-treated netting, pyrethroid insecticides
  • DEET-based insect repellent (lower malaria rates)
  • Chloroquine/hydroxychloroquine prophylaxis is safe in pregnancy
  • Some antimalarials contraindicated (atovaquone/proguanil, primaquine, doxycycline)

questions.text: The subcostal line corresponds to which vertebrae level?

A 45-year-old HIV patient presents with persistent headaches, confusion, and a gradual onset of fever. A lumbar puncture is performed, revealing an elevated opening pressure and a cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a positive india ink stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast.

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis.

Serotypes

A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii

Virulence factors
  • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.
  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.
  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:
    • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.
    • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

  • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

  • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

  • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans.

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci.

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.text: A 65-year-old smoker presents with ulcerative lesions on his lower lip for the past year. On examination, there is a palpable ipsilateral submental lymph node approximately 5x5 cm. A biopsy from the lesion is suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. What is the next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Resection of primary lesion with lip reconstruction and MRND

questions.correct_answer: D. Resection of primary lesion with lip reconstruction and MRND
questions.explanation:
T Stage

  • Tis: Carcinoma in situ
  • T1: Tumor ≤2 cm and ≤5 mm depth of invasion
  • T2: Tumor ≤2 cm and >5 mm but ≤10 mm depth, OR
    Tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm and ≤10 mm depth
  • T3: Tumor >4 cm OR any tumor >10 mm depth of invasion
  • T4: Invasion of adjacent structures

N Stage:

  • N0: No regional lymph node metastasis
  • N1-N3: Based on number, size, and laterality of involved nodes

M Stage:

  • M0: No distant metastasis
  • M1: Distant metastasis

Early Stage (T1-T2N0)
  • Wide local excision with 1 cm margins
  • Consider elective neck dissection for tumours>2 cm or >4 mm in depth
  • Reconstruction: Primary closure, local flaps, or skin grafts

Advanced Stage (T3-T4 or N+)
  • Wide local excision with ≥1 cm margins
  • Neck dissection (comprehensive or selective based on nodal status)
  • Complex reconstruction (local/regional flaps, free tissue transfer)
  • Adjuvant radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy based on pathological findings

Reconstruction Options
  • Wedge excision and primary closure (for small lesions)
  • Local flaps: Abbe-Estlander, Karapandzic, nasolabial
  • Regional flaps: Forehead, cervicofacial
  • Free tissue transfer: Radial forearm free flap, anterolateral thigh flap

Management of the Neck
  • Elective neck dissection for high-risk tumours (>2 cm, >4 mm depth)
  • Therapeutic neck dissection for clinically positive nodes
  • Levels typically addressed: I-III for N0 neck, I-V for N+ neck

Radiotherapy
  • Adjuvant: For positive margins, perineural invasion, multiple positive nodes
  • Definitive: For patients unfit for surgery or refusing surgery
  • Brachytherapy: Can be considered for select early-stage lesions

Chemotherapy
  • Not routinely used in early-stage disease
  • It may be combined with radiotherapy in locally advanced cases

Follow-up and Surveillance

Regular follow-up visits: Every 1-3 months for the first year, then gradually decreasing frequency

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was presented in the psychiatric OPD with complaints of inattention at school, hitting his friends and excessive talking, poor academic performance, and inability to sit in a place for a long time. What drug is used in the management of this disorder?
questions.explanation:
Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)

Aetiology

  • Genetic Factors: Runs in families, with parents or siblings more likely to have the condition (DAT1 gene and DRD4 gene).
  • Neurochemical Factors: Linked to dopamine dysfunction and noradrenergic system.
  • Neurophysiological Factors: EEG usually shows theta and beta waves in the frontal brain.
  • Neuroanatomical Factors: Decreased activity in brain areas like the prefrontal cortex, anterior cingulate, and basal ganglia.
  • Developmental Factors: Prenatal and perinatal factors, such as premature birth, maternal infections during pregnancy, and low birth weight, may increase the risk.
  • Psychosocial Factors: Severe abuse, neglect, or maltreatment can worsen or mimic ADHD symptoms.

Clinical features

  • Hyperactivity: Restlessness, difficulty remaining seated, inappropriate running and climbing, excessive talking, interrupting others.
  • Attention Deficit: Short attention span, distractibility, difficulty following instructions, forgetfulness, disorganisation, procrastination.
  • Impulsivity: Acting without thinking, difficulty waiting for their turn, interrupting others, blurting out answers.
  • Other: Emotional lability, explosiveness, irritability, memory and thinking defects, specific learning difficulties, speech and Hearing deficits.

Diagnosis

For an ADHD diagnosis to be confirmed, symptoms must be present in at least two different environments, such as both school and home. This ensures that the behaviour is not limited to one specific context and indicates a broader issue with attention and self-regulation.

Treatment

Pharmacotherapy

  • Stimulant Medication:
    • Methylphenidate (1st drug of choice)
    • Amphetamine (2nd drug of choice)
    • Modafinil (not FDA-approved) (Option B ruled out)
  • Non-stimulant medication
    • Atomoxetine
    • Bupropion (not FDA-approved for ADHD)

 

Psychosocial interventions

Subtypes of ADHD

Combined Presentation

Predominantly Inattentive Presentation

Predominantly Hyperactive/Impulsive Presentation

6 or more symptoms of both inattention and Hyperactivity-Impulsivity
  • 6 or more symptoms of Inattention
  • <6 symptoms of Hyperactivity-Impulsivity
  • 6 or more symptoms of Hyperactivity/Impulsive subtype
  • <6 symptoms of Inattention

  • Surgical repair (myringoplasty) if not healed in 6–8 weeks

Which of the following is the preferred drug for the treatment of postmenopausal breast cancer?
questions.explanation:
Hormonal therapy for breast cancer

Drug

Given for

Clinical Correlation

Tamoxifen

Pre-menopausal hormone receptor-positive breast cancer

Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) works by blocking estrogen receptors on breast cancer cells, which can slow or stop the growth of tumors that require estrogen to grow.

Anastrozole

Post-menopausal hormone receptor-positive breast cancer

Aromatase inhibitors reduce the production of estrogen in the body by blocking the enzyme aromatase, which converts androgens into estrogen in postmenopausal women.

Fulvestrant

Hormone receptor-positive metastatic breast cancer

Estrogen receptor antagonists work by binding to estrogen receptors and degrading them, which helps to reduce the growth of estrogen-dependent cancer cells.

Trastuzumab

HER2-positive breast cancer

Monoclonal antibodies that target the HER2 receptor inhibit the growth of cancer cells and can also recruit the body's immune system to destroy these cells.

questions.text: What is the next step in the management of a suspected tubal pregnancy with inconclusive transvaginal ultrasound?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Modality

Findings for Unruptured Ectopic Pregnancy

Beta hCG Levels
  • Failure to double the value of β-hCG in 48 hours
  • Lower concentration of β-hCG than expected for gestational age

Transvaginal Sonography (TVS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac within the uterine cavity when β-hCG ≥ 1500 IU/L.
  • Adnexal Mass: An adnexal mass clearly separate from the ovary (Blob sign).
  • Ring-of-Fire Pattern: Increased blood flow around the ectopic mass on Color Doppler.
  • Presence of pseudo gestational sac.
  • Free fluid in the Pouch of Douglas

Transabdominal Sonography (TAS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac when β-hCG ≥ 6,000 IU/L
  • Other features: May be visible but less sensitive than TVS for smaller masses

Blood examination
  • Haemoglobin
  • ABO and Rh grouping
  • Total white cell count and differential count
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)

Estimation of β-hCG
  • Lower concentration of β-hCG compared to normal intrauterine pregnancy
  • Plasma concentration does not double in 48 hours like in normal pregnancy

Sonography (TVS)

The diagnostic features are:

  • Absence of intrauterine pregnancy with a positive pregnancy test.
  • Fluid (echogenic) in the pouch of Douglas.
  • Adnexal mass clearly separated from the ovary (Blob sign).
  • Rarely cardiac motion may be seen in an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy.

 

Combination of quantitative β-hCG values and sonog­raphy
  • TVS provides visualization of a well-formed intrauterine gestational sac as early as 4–5 weeks from the last menstrual period.
  • The lowest level of serum β-hCG at which a gestational sac is consistently visible using TVS (discriminatory zone) is ≥ 1,500 IU/L.
  • So if the beta-hCG level is≥ 1,500 and no intrauterine pregnancy is seen, an ectopic pregnancy is highly suspected.

 

Laparoscopy

Offers benefits in cases of confusion with other pelvic lesions

Dilatation and curettage

Identification of decidua without villi structure is suggestive.

Serum progesterone

A level greater than 25 ng/mL is suggestive of viable intrauterine pregnancy whereas a level less than 5 ng/mL suggests an ectopic or abnormal intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Laparotomy

Used when in doubt

questions.text: A 70 year old male patient presents to the OPD with multiple, recurrent fainting episodes. An ECG was taken and it shows P waves at a rate of 75 bpm and qrs complexes at a rate of 35 bpm. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Third-degree atrioventricular block / Stokes-Adams Syndrome

Definition

Complete failure of conduction between atria and ventricles, resulting in independent beating (AV dissociation).

Ventricular Activity

Maintained by an escape rhythm from:

  • The AV node or bundle of His (narrow QRS complexes).
  • Distal Purkinje tissues (broad QRS complexes).

ECG Findings
  • Prolonged PR interval
  • Broad QRS complex
  • Number of P waves will not be equal to the number of R waves
  • P-R interval (atrial rate) will not match the R-R interval (ventricular rate)

Clinical Features
  • Recurrent syncope or 'Stokes–Adams' attacks- sudden loss of consciousness and collapse.
  • Brief anoxic seizure.
  • Pallor and a death-like appearance during the attack; characteristic flush upon recovery.
  • Rapid recovery distinguishes it from epilepsy.

Management
  • Depends on clinical circumstances.
  • Transient AV block in acute inferior myocardial infarction- no treatment if the patient remains stable.
  • Symptomatic third-degree AV block- intravenous atropine or intravenous isoprenaline to maintain circulation until temporary pacing is inserted.
  • Permanent pacemaker.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with a gradually progressive swelling over the abdomen for 1.5 years. She has a history of midline surgery. On examination, the swelling is 4 cm and is reducible with a palpable cough impulse. She is planning to undergo fascial closure with mesh repair. What is the most likely location of the mesh shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Technique

Mesh Placement

Procedure

Advantages

Disadvantages

Inlay

Within the fascial defect itself

Mesh is sutured to the edges of the fascial defect.

It can be used for large defects where primary closure isn't possible.

High recurrence rates due to mesh separation from fascial edges under abdominal pressure

Onlay

On top of the anterior rectus sheath/external oblique aponeurosis

Subcutaneous tissue is dissected off; the fascial defect is closed primarily, and the mesh is placed on top and secured

Technically easier and less invasive.

Higher risk of seroma formation, mesh infection, and skin necrosis.

Retromuscular

 

Behind the rectus muscle but anterior to the posterior rectus sheath

The posterior rectus sheath is opened, the mesh is placed in the created space, and the posterior sheath is closed over it

Lower recurrence rates, mesh well incorporated into tissues

More complex procedure, risk of injury to neurovascular bundles.

Preperitoneal

 

Between the peritoneum and the posterior rectus sheath.

Peritoneum is separated from the posterior rectus sheath; mesh is placed in this space, and the peritoneum is closed over it.

Good mesh incorporation, lower risk of adhesions.

Technically challenging, risk of peritoneal tears.

questions.text: A patient who received a supraclavicular brachial plexus block with 0.5% bupivacaine develops hypotension and arrhythmias. What is the first-line treatment for this situation?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features

CNS effects:

  • Early and less severe.
  • First symptom: circumoral paraesthesia
  • First sign: nystagmus
  • At low plasma concentration: mild sensory disturbances.
  • Increased concentration: CNS excitation, seizure activity.
  • Higher concentration: CNS depression, coma, respiratory depression, arrest.

Cardiac effects:

  • Usually late but severe form of toxicity, may lead to death.
  • Hypotension, dysrhythmias, myocardial depression.
  • Potent agents (bupivacaine, ropivacaine, levobupivacaine) linked to cardiovascular collapse, heart block.

Safety profile

Bupivacaine has more risk to cause LAST than Lidocaine

Most potent highly lipid soluble drugs are more likely to cause

Prevention
  • Risk recognition and dose reduction.
  • Careful aspiration before injection.
  • Incremental administration (3-5 mL) with continuous heart rate monitoring.
  • Use ultrasonographic guidance to confirm anesthetic deposit.
  • Use a vasoactive agent like epinephrine to reduce systemic absorption and serve as an intravascular indicator.

Treatment
  • Recognize LAST (Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity) early and call for help.
  • Airway management: Secure airway, ventilate with 100% oxygen.
  • Administer 20% Lipid Emulsion:
    • Bolus: 12 mL/kg over 2-3 min.
    • Infusion: at 0.25 mL/kg/min-0.5ml/kg/min for 15-20 mins
    • Maximum initial dose: 12 ml/kg
  • Administration of antiepileptics: for seizure control, benzodiazepines such as Lorazepam is preferred.
  • Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: if necessary, monitor the patient at least for initial 2-6 hours following resuscitation.

A patient complains of difficulty breathing, and fatigue. On examination, distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds were found. X-ray is shown below. Identify the disease.
questions.explanation:
Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

Fatigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

Investigation

Purpose/Details

Chest X-ray
  • Egg in a cup appearance
  • Detects pericardial calcification, a key diagnostic clue.

Echocardiography

Visualises thickened pericardium and assesses cardiac function.

CT scanning

Helps in visualising pericardial calcification.

Complex echo-Doppler and cardiac catheterisation

  • Square root wave sign
  • Used to differentiate constrictive pericarditis from restrictive cardiomyopathy when diagnosis is uncertain.

Management Type

Treatment

Purpose/Details

Medical Management

Diuretics (e.g., loop diuretics, spironolactone)

Helps manage diastolic heart failure by reducing fluid overload.

Surgical Management

Pericardiectomy

 

Definitive treatment through surgical removal of the diseased pericardium. Significant improvement is possible, but the procedure has high complication risk and suboptimal outcomes in up to 50% of patients.

  • LINAC- Linear accelerators do not need a radioisotope
  • The fast-moving electron beam generates radiation which is used in radiotherapy
  • X-ray beams are produced

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary identification made by a CBNAAT/ gene expert?
questions.explanation:
Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

  • Initial screening for pulmonary TB.
  • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.
  • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.
  • Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.
  • Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods
  • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.
  • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.
  • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.
  • The gold standard for TB diagnosis.
  • Allows for drug susceptibility testing.
  • Time-consuming; results can take weeks.
  • Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF
  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.
  • Method:
  • A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).
  • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.
  • Rapid results (within 2 hours).
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.
  • More expensive than smear microscopy.
  • Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)
  • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Method:
  • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.
  • Sputum or other specimens are used.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).
  • High specificity and sensitivity.
  • Can be performed at the point of care.
  • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.
  • Less widely available than PCR-based tests.
  • Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat
  • Point-of-care test for TB detection.
  • Method:
  • Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.
  • Results are available within 60 minutes.
  • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.
  • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.

 

Line Probe Assay (LPA)

 
  • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).
  • Method:
    • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.
    • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 days).
  • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.
  • Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.
  • Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP
  • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis.
  • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

questions.text: A Patient who has a pet dog at home complains of hypochondrial pain. Radiological imaging shows a multilocular cyst within the liver. The organism involved is?
questions.explanation:
Echinococcus granulosus

Other name

Dog tapeworm

Definitive Host

Dog (optimal host), wolf, jackal and fox

Intermediate Host

Sheep and cattle

Accidental Intermediate Host

Man (Harbors larval stage, not adult form)

Infective Form

Embryonated egg

Mode of Infection

Ingestion of the eggs due to:

  • Intimate handling of infected dogs
  • Eating raw vegetables or other food items contaminated with dog feces

Eggs

  • Ovoid in shape and brown in color
  • Contains an embryo with three pairs of hooklets

Larva

Represent structure of scolex of adult worm and remains invaginated within a vesicular body.

Adult Worm
  • Consist of scolex, a short neck and strobila
  • Scolex is pyriform, with four suckers and prominent rostellum bearing two circular rows of hooklets.

Layer

Name

Origin

Description

Main Function

Outer Layer

Pericyst

Host-derived
  • Thick fibrous layer created by the host's inflammatory response around the cyst.
  • Eventually it develops into a dense fibrous capsule which may even calcify.

Provides structural support and isolates the cyst from surrounding tissues.

Middle Layer

Ectocyst (Laminated Membrane)

Parasite-derived
  • Acellular,chitinous, laminated hyaline layer secreted by the parasite.
  • Has the appearance of the white of a hard boiled egg.

Acts as a barrier against host immune cells and protects the inner germinal layer.

Inner Layer

Endocyst (Germinal Layer)

Parasite-derived
  • Thin cellular layer lining the cyst interior.
  • Consist of a number of nuclei embedded in a protoplasmic mass.
  • Vital layer of the cyst.
  • Site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.
  • Also secrete hydatid fluid, which fills the cyst.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is not included in the definition of severe Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR)?
questions.explanation:
Category

Management

Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR):

No Diabetic Retinopathy

Review in 12 months

Very Mild NPDR

Microaneurysms only

Review most patients in 12 months

 

Mild NPDR

Any or all of the: microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton-wool spots, up to the level of moderate NPDR. No intraretinal microvascular anomalies (IRMA) or significant beading.

Review range 6-12 months, depending on the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and patient's circumstances

Moderate NPDR

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA
  • Significant venous beading can be present in no more than 1 quadrant
  • Cotton wool spots commonly present

Review in approximately 6 months

 

Severe NPDR

The 4-2-1 rule; is one or more of the:

  • Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants (Option B ruled out)
  • Significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants (Option D ruled out)
  • Moderate IRMA in 1 or more quadrants (Option A ruled out)

Review in 4 months

Very severe NPDR

Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR

Review in 2-3 months

questions.text: Identify the condition that presents with an empty delta sign.
The chest X-ray shows right-sided white-out lung and contralateral tracheal deviation. In which of the following conditions is this seen?

A 28-year-old woman with a recent travel history to Africa presents with fever, confusion and neurological deficits. Laboratory analysis reveals the following findings. This organism exhibits a specific property that facilitates sequestration in vascular beds to avoid splenic clearance. What is the phenomenon called?
A patient with meningitis was examined. His CSF shows lymphocytosis, decreased glucose, and increased protein. What is the etiological agent?
questions.explanation:
TB Meningitis

Pathophysiology
  • Tuberculous Meningitis results from hematogenous spread of primary or postprimary TB or rupture of a subependymal tubercle into the subarachnoid space.

Onset

Evolves over 1–2 weeks, slower than bacterial meningitis.

Symptoms
  • Early Symptoms
    • Headache, mild mental changes, low-grade fever, malaise, anorexia, irritability over several weeks.
  • Advanced Symptoms
    • Severe headache, confusion, lethargy, altered sensorium, neck rigidity, cranial nerve palsies (especially ocular). Can progress to coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension.

Lumbar Puncture Findings (CSF)
  • High leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL), typically lymphocyte predominance
  • Protein: 1–8 g/L (100–800 mg/dL)
  • Low glucose concentration
  • AFB is rarely seen; repeated lumbar punctures increase yield.
  • CSF culture diagnostic in up to 80% (gold standard).

Xpert MTB/RIF Assay
  • Sensitivity up to 80%.
  • A negative result does not exclude TB.

Imaging
  • CT, MRI: Shows hydrocephalus and enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.

Basal cistern enhancement

  • In >50% of cases, old pulmonary lesions or military pattern on CXR.

Treatment

Immediate treatment with positive Xpert MTB/RIF.

  • Chemotherapy is effective but neurologic sequelae occur in 25% of cases, especially with delayed diagnosis.
  • Glucocorticoid Therapy
    • Dexamethasone reduces mortality and severe disability but may not prevent neurological sequelae.
    • Regimen: 0.4 mg/kg/day IV, tapering weekly, followed by oral tapering. WHO recommends tapering over 6–8 weeks.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient on immunosuppressive therapy presents with a cough, fever, and pneumonia. A biopsy reveals the given findings. Which organism is responsible for the infection?
questions.explanation:
CMV (cytomegalovirus)

Class

Betaherpesvirinae subfamily of the Herpesviridae family.

Modes of transmission
  • Oral route, respiratory & body secretions (most common)
  • Vertical transmission
  • Sexual transmission
  • Organ transplantation
  • Blood transfusion

Host cells
  • Salivary gland
  • Kidney

Clinical features

Congenital infection

  • Most common intrauterine infection with congenital defects.
  • Common presentation:
    • Petechiae
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Jaundice
  • Less common presentation:
    • Microcephaly
    • Cerebral calcifications
    • Intrauterine growth retardation
    • Prematurity
  • Other defects: Sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Perinatal infection

  • Commonly asymptomatic.
  • Occasionally, premature infants present with interstitial pneumonitis.

 

Immunocompromised

  • This is seen in AIDS, HIV, organ transplant patients and cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
  • Presentations in AIDS and HIV
    • CMV chorioretinitis
    • Progressive dementia,
    • Cranial nerve defects,
  • Presentations in Organ transplant
    • Bilateral interstitial pneumonia
    • Febrile leukopenia
    • Obliterative bronchiolitis
    • Graft atherosclerosis
    • Rejection of renal allografts.

 

Immunocompetent

  • Usually, it occurs following a blood transfusion.
  • It presents similar to infectious mononucleosis, but heterophile antibody tests would be negative.

Investigations

Peripheral smear: Owl’s eye appearance of inclusion bodies.

 

 

Virus isolation

It is done by

  • Human fibroblast cell line culture
  • Shell vial culture

 

Antigen detected: PP65

 

Antibody detection

It is done by ELISA, and the antibodies detected are

  • CMV IgM antibodies
  • CMV IgG antibodies
  • Against PP150 and PP65,
  • Against the PP52

 

PCR

  • Used in detecting CMV DNA
  • Quantitative nucleic acid testing (QNAT) by PCR is the most sensitive and specific testing.

Treatment
  • Ganciclovir (Drug of choice)
  • Foscarnet (in Ganciclovir resistance)
  • CMV immunoglobulins and Ganciclovir are given to bone marrow transplant patients.

questions.text: A lung cancer patient has hyperpigmentation of palmar and sole creases. Which of the following is responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ectopic Cushing's Syndrome

Definition

ACTH production from non-pituitary sources leading to Cushing's syndrome

Epidemiology

Accounts for 10-20% of cases of Cushing's syndrome

Common Sources
  • Small cell lung cancer (most common)
  • Bronchial and thymic carcinoids
  • Islet tumors
  • Pheochromocytomas
  • Medullary thyroid carcinomas

Pathophysiology
  • Increased expression of POMC gene from non-pituitary sources
  • Production of MSH, β-lipotropin, and other POMC-derived peptides
  • Production of ACTH fragments

Clinical Features
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Marked fluid retention
  • Hyperpigmentation manifestations due to MSH
  • Less marked weight gain compared to pituitary Cushing's
  • Centripetal fat redistribution
  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Glucose intolerance

Diagnosis
  • Very high ACTH levels (typically >2-3 times normal)
  • No response to high-dose dexamethasone suppression

Treatment
  • Treatment of underlying malignancy
  • Glucocorticoid receptor blockers
  • Steroidogenesis inhibitors
  • Management of complications (diabetes, hypokalemia)

Key Distinctions from Pituitary Cushing's
  • Higher ACTH levels
  • No response to dexamethasone suppression
  • More rapid onset
  • More severe metabolic complications

questions.text: Which hormone increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep?
questions.explanation:
Factors controlling GH secretion and their effects

Hypothalamic Control
  • Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone (GHRH): Increases GH synthesis and secretion.
  • Somatostatin (GHIH): Decreases GH secretion.

Nutritional Factors
  • Hypoglycemia: Promotes GH secretion to increase blood glucose levels and mobilize energy.
  • Amino Acids: Stimulate GH release, supporting protein synthesis and growth.
  • Starvation or Protein Deficiency: This leads to elevated GH levels to conserve body proteins and utilize fats as an energy source.

Physiological Factors
  • Exercise: Enhances GH secretion
  • Sleep: GH surges during deep sleep are vital for growth and tissue repair processes.
  • Stress: Physical and emotional stressors can increase GH secretion

Hormonal Factors
  • Ghrelin: Increases GH secretion and stimulates appetite.
  • Sex Hormones (Estrogen and Testosterone): Contribute to increased GH secretion during puberty, supporting growth and development.
  • Negative Feedback Control: GH and IGF-1 levels feedback to inhibit further GH release, maintaining homeostasis and preventing excess GH production.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male soldier complained of being plagued by a painful, erosive lesion near his earlobe since his return from his duty in the desert area. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and general physical examinations reveal no other abnormalities. The punch biopsy of the leading edge of the erosion reveals the given findings. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Kala-azar/ Black sickness/Dum-dum fever/Sandfly disease/ Visceral Leishmaniasis

Organism

Protozoan

Epidemiology

Endemic in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal

Types
  1. Visceral (Kala-Azar): L. donovani
  2. Cutaneous: L. tropica
  3. Mucocutaneous: L. braziliensis
  4. Post-kala-azar dermal (PKLD): Immune response

Reservoir
  • Humans (non-zoonotic)

Vector
  • Sandfly (Phlebotomus argentipes): has hairy wings.

Environmental
  • Peak outbreak: November to April

Mechanism of transmission
  • Bite of sandfly
  • Blood transfusion (rare)

Incubation period
  • 10 days to 2 years. (1-4 months average)

Clinical features
  • Visceral: Fever, Weight loss, Hepatosplenomegaly, Anemia.
  • Cutaneous: Painful skin ulcers
  • Mucocutaneous: Rapid mucosal destruction of nose and oropharynx
  • PKDL: Skin nodules filled with micro-organisms

Diagnosis
  • Rapid diagnostic kits: rk39-dipstick test.
    • Used for field surveys.
  • Biopsy (Gold standard): Leishmania Donovan bodies (amastigotes)

Sandfly control measures
  • DDT: 1-2gm/m2.
  • BHC (benzene hexachloride)

Treatment
  • DOC: Single dose Liposomal amphotericin-B (LAMB)10 mg/kg
  • Alternatives:
    • Miltefosine + Paramomycin
    • Pentamidine

questions.text: A young lady gave a history of unprotected intercourse four days back. She is requesting an emergency contraception. Which of the following is most suitable in this case?
The patient is having the following hand movements. In which of the following conditions would this be seen?
Utilizing the provided X-ray, identify the type of fracture using the Salter-Harris classification?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Treatment and Prognosis

Type I (Option A)

Separation of the physis (growth plate), without involvement of the metaphysis or epiphysis.
  • Excellent prognosis if treated promptly
  • Treated with immobilization and observation.

Type II (Option B)

Fracture through the physis and part of the metaphysis. The metaphyseal fragment is displaced, forming a triangle (known as the Thurston-Holland sign).
  • Good prognosis with proper treatment.
  • Treated with reduction and casting.
  • Rarely affects future growth.

Type III (Option C)

Fracture through the physis and epiphysis, with the epiphysis displaced.
  • May result in joint deformity or growth disturbance if not managed well.
  • Surgical intervention required for proper alignment and fixation.

Type IV

Fracture through the physis, metaphysis, and epiphysis. Involves all three areas.
  • Can lead to growth disturbances or joint deformity.
  • Treatment typically involves surgical fixation.

Type V (Option D)

Crushing injury of the physis (growth plate), resulting in compression and loss of the growth plate. No fracture line visible.
  • Risk of growth arrest and long-term deformities.
  • Surgical intervention required.

Causes:

questions.explanation:
Treatment of RCC: RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant.

Surgical Management:

Partial Nephrectomy (Option A): Involves removing only the tumour while preserving the remainder of the kidney.

Indications:

  • T1 Disease(<7cm)
  • Restricted to poles
  • RCC in solitary functioning kidney
  • Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim.
  • Indications: Larger tumours or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible

Ablative Techniques

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation Involve destroying the tumor using extreme temperatures.

Indications:

  • Patients who are not surgical candidates
  • Patients with small tumours (T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm).

Systemic Therapy

(For advanced/ metastatic disease)

Targeted Therapy

  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib)
  • mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus)

Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab)

Definition
  • Inflammation of inner structures of the eye (uveal tissue and retina) with exudates in the vitreous, anterior, and posterior chambers. It spares sclera.

M/C causative organism
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis

Presentation

  • Severe ocular pain
  • Redness
  • Lacrimation
  • Photophobia
  • Loss of vision
  • Red and swollen lids
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Circumcorneal congestion
  • Cloudy cornea
  • Ring infiltration
  • Yellow necrotic wound edges
  • Hypopyon
  • Oedematous and muddy iris

questions.text: A 30-year-old female who is receiving cyclosporine A following renal transplantation develops multiple and bilateral breast lumps that regress after cessation of the treatment. Biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 17-year-old boy who fell on an outstretched hand is now experiencing pain and swelling at the base of the thumb. Which bone is most likely fractured?
questions.explanation:
Scaphoid fracture

Site

  • Waist of scaphoid (most common)
  • Distal pole (Least common)
  • Proximal pole (high risk for avascular necrosis)

Mechanism of injury

Typically caused by a fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) with the wrist in dorsiflexion.

Clinical features

  • It is more common in young adults, particularly athletes.
  • Pain and tenderness localised to the anatomical snuffbox (the depression between the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and the abductor pollicis longus/extensor pollicis brevis).
  • Swelling and reduced range of motion at the wrist.

X-ray

There is a visible fracture line at the waist of the scaphoid, with possible cortical disruption or displacement; avascular necrosis may later appear as sclerosis in the proximal pole.

Management

Immobilisation by scaphoid cast (3-4 months)

Complications

  • Avascular necrosis (more common in the proximal pole)
  • Humpback deformity (displaced Scaphoid fracture)
  • Delayed and non-union
  • Wrist osteoarthritis

questions.text: A patient has muffled heart sounds with low blood pressure. What is the correct JVP finding?
questions.explanation:
Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Clinical Features

Beck's triad

  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other features

Pulsus Paradoxus: A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the rate-limiting enzyme of the hexose monophosphate (HMP) pathway?
questions.explanation:
Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP)

The Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP), also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt, is an alternative metabolic pathway for glucose that doesn't generate ATP.

Location: Cytosol
It serves two primary functions:

NADPH Production
  • The PPP is a major source of NADPH, vital for biosynthesis (fatty acids and steroids).
  • NADPH Production: RBCs rely on glycolysis for ATP due to the lack of mitochondria and depend solely on the PPP for NADPH, as they lack mitochondrial dehydrogenases.
  • Glutathione Maintenance: NADPH keeps glutathione reduced, enabling glutathione peroxidase to neutralize hydrogen peroxide and prevent oxidative damage.
  • Impact of NADPH Deficiency: Low NADPH reduces glutathione, impairs glutathione peroxidase, increases oxidative damage, and leads to hemolysis.

Ribose-5-Phosphate (R-5-P) Synthesis
  • Ribose-5-phosphate is essential for nucleotide synthesis needed for RNA and DNA.

Homeostasis between NADPH and R-5-P

production.
  • When NADPH demand exceeds R-5-P's need, the non-oxidative phase converts R-5-P to glycolytic intermediates (fructose-6-phosphate and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate).
  • If the demand for R-5-P is higher than for NADPH, the non-oxidative phase generates R-5-P from fructose-6-phosphate and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate, bypassing the oxidative steps.

Differences from Glycolysis
  • Uses NADP+ instead of NAD+ and generates CO2, not ATP.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is least likely to be associated with the use of amiodarone?
questions.explanation:
Amiodarone

MOA
  • It prolongs action potential duration and QT interval by blocking delayed rectifier K+ channels.
  • Blocks inactivated Na+ channels, with rapid channel recovery (Decrease phase 0 slope).
  • It partially inhibits myocardial Ca2+ channels, adding to its antiarrhythmic effects.
  • It is used to treat both atrial and ventricular fibrillation.

Drug interactions
  • Inhibits CYP3A4, CYP2C9, and P-glycoprotein, leading to potential interactions with drugs metabolized by this system.
  • Increases plasma levels of digoxin and warfarin.
  • Additive AV block with beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.

Adverse reactions
  • Hypotension and Bradycardia (with i.v administration or after drug accumulation)
  • Photosensitivity: Skin pigmentation - Purple colour (purple man syndrome, smurf syndrome)
  • Corneal microdeposits: Reversible upon drug discontinuation.
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis, on long-term use (Option D ruled out)
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Interfere with thyroid function as it acts as a source of iodine and can potentially lead to goitre, hypothyroidism (Wolf Chaikoff effect), or, in rare cases, hyperthyroidism (Jos-Basedow effect). (Option A and B ruled out)

questions.text: Drug of choice for acute rheumatic fever?
questions.explanation:
Management of ARF

Treatment for

Medication used

Group streptococcal infection
  • Penicillin/Erythromycin/Azithromycin.
  • 10 days or oral Amoxicillin or a single dose of IM benzathine penicillin.
  • Azithromycin in case of Penicillin allergy.

Symptomatic management
  • Salicylates like aspirin (NSAIDs as an alternative option)
  • It is the first-line treatment for arthritis, fever, and inflammation. Dose: High initially, then taper as symptoms improve.

Carditis
  • Corticosteroids.
  • Diuretics like Furosemide are used if heart failure symptoms due to rheumatic carditis are present. (Option D ruled out)

Chorea
  • It is managed conservatively, or Valproic acid is used for the sedation

CCF

Diuretics and vasodilators are used.

Prophylaxis

(is essential to prevent recurrent infections and further damage to the heart)

Inj. Benzathine penicillin is given every 3-4 weeks IM

  • 6 lakh IU in children ≤27 kg.
  • 1.2 million IU in children >27 kg

Bed rest is advised

Major criteria

Minor criteria
  • Clinical or subclinical evidence of carditis (e.g., new murmur)
  • Migratory polyarthritis (Two or more joints involved)
  • Sydenham chorea (involuntary movements)
  • Erythema marginatum (characteristic skin rash)
  • Subcutaneous nodules
  • Previous rheumatic fever or rheumatic heart disease
  • Fever (≥38.5°C)
  • Poly or mono arthralgia
  • Elevated acute phase reactants (e.g., CRP, ESR)
  • Prolonged PR interval on ECG

The presence of two major criteria, or one major criterion + two minor criteria (along with evidence of preceding streptococcal infection), supports the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) according to the Jones criteria.
